list-item.p: Educational Forum for Highly Capable Students and Their Families cohosted by the Robinson Center for Young Scholars and the University of Washington at the University of Washington in Seattle, WA. For more information, please visit http://www.scholarsearchassoc.com/

boxed-text.title: Did you know that . . .
boxed-text.p: . . . 76% of the public thinks that high-achieving high school students should be recruited to become teachers.
. . . 70% of the public believes that the ability to teach is more the result of natural talent than of college training.
. . . 67% of the public would like to have their child take up teaching in the public schools as a career.
. . . 52% of the public thinks their local public school system has a hard time getting good teachers.
. . . 68% of the public hears more bad stories about teachers in the news media.
. . . 71% of the public has trust and confidence in the men and women who are teaching children in the public schools.
. . . 26% of the public believes that education policies should require teachers to follow a prescribed curriculum.
. . . 73% of the public believes that teachers should be given flexibility to teach in ways they think best.
. . . 47% of the public believes that teacher unions have hurt the quality of public school education.
. . . 89% of the public believes that the level of academic degree earned is somewhat to very important in determining a public school teacher’s salary.
. . . 82% of the public believes that experience is somewhat to very important in determining a public school teacher’s salary.
. . . 73% of the public believes that student test scores are somewhat to very important in determining a public school teacher’s salary.
. . . 36% of the public thinks the biggest problem that public schools of their community must deal with is lack of financial support.
. . . 79% of the public would give the public school that their oldest child attends a grade of A or B.
. . . 51% of the public would give the public schools in their community a grade of A or B.
. . . 17% of the public would give the public schools in the nation a grade of A or B.
. . . 69% of the public would give the public school teachers in their community a grade of A or B.
. . . 54% of the public would give the public school principals in their community a grade of A or B.
. . . 37% of the public would give the school board in their community a grade of A or B.
. . . 70% of the public favors charter schools.
. . . 74% of the public favors allowing the student and his or her parents’ choice in which public schools in the community the students attend, regardless of where they live.
. . . 65% of the public opposes allowing students and parents to choose a private school to attend at public expense.
Statistics from Bushaw, W. J., & Lopez, S. J. (2011). The 43rd annual Phi Delta Kappa/Gallup Poll of the public’s attitudes toward the public schools. Phi Delta Kappan, 93(1), 9-26.
